content:
Great timing! Congratulations on taking the first step towards reducing your screen time and taking control of your social media usage!

Yes, excessive social media use has been linked to negative effects on mental health, including increased anxiety, depression, and loneliness. Tracking and limiting your social media use is a great way to regain control and develop healthier habits.

Here are some excellent phone apps that can help you track and limit your social media use:

1. **Freedom**: This app blocks distracting websites and apps across all your devices, including social media platforms. You can set custom block sessions, schedule blocks in advance, and track your productivity.
2. **Moment**: This app tracks your screen time, including social media use, and provides detailed reports on your habits. It also offers features like app blocking, goal-setting, and coaching to help you stay on track.
3. **StayFocused**: A Chrome extension and mobile app that blocks social media sites and other distracting websites during certain times of the day or for a set period.
4. **RescueTime**: This app tracks how you spend your time on your phone, including social media use, and provides insights into your productivity and time management.
5. **Screen Time**: A built-in feature on iOS devices (and similar apps like Digital Wellbeing on Android) that tracks your screen time, sets app limits, and provides insights into your usage habits.
6. **Cold Turkey**: A website blocker and app that helps you stay focused on your goals by blocking social media and other distracting websites during set periods.
7. **Flipd**: An app that helps you stay focused on your goals by blocking social media and other distracting apps, as well as tracking your productivity and providing motivational reminders.
8. **SelfControl**: A free, open-source app for Mac and Linux that blocks distracting websites and emails for a set period, helping you stay focused on your tasks.

These apps can help you develop healthier habits and reduce your screen time. Remember, the key is to set realistic goals and be consistent in your efforts.

It's great that you read that article in The New Yorker and it inspired you to make a change. Good luck on your journey to reducing your screen time and improving your mental health!
